sub_topic: Finding the maximum or minimum value of a trigonometric function
message_1: A Ferris wheel has a maximum height of 50 meters and a minimum height of 10 meters. The wheel takes 5 minutes to complete one full revolution. Write an equation to represent the height of the Ferris wheel as a function of time and find the maximum and minimum heights reached by the Ferris wheel during one revolution.
message_2:
Let h(t) represent the height of the Ferris wheel as a function of time t (in minutes). Since the Ferris wheel oscillates between its maximum and minimum heights, we can model its height using a sinusoidal function.

The amplitude of the function is half the difference between the maximum and minimum heights: (50 - 10) / 2 = 40 / 2 = 20 meters.

The vertical shift (or the average height) is the average of the maximum and minimum heights: (50 + 10) / 2 = 60 / 2 = 30 meters.

The period of the function is the time it takes for the Ferris wheel to complete one full revolution, which is 5 minutes. To find the angular frequency (ω), we use the formula:

ω = 2π / period

ω = 2π / 5

Now we can write the height function h(t) as a sinusoidal function:

h(t) = amplitude × sin(ωt) + vertical shift

h(t) = 20 × sin((2π / 5)t) + 30

The maximum height is reached when the sine function is at its maximum value, which is 1:

max height = 20 × 1 + 30 = 20 + 30 = 50 meters

The minimum height is reached when the sine function is at its minimum value, which is -1:

min height = 20 × (-1) + 30 = -20 + 30 = 10 meters

So, the equation representing the height of the Ferris wheel as a function of time is:

h(t) = 20 × sin((2π / 5)t) + 30

And the maximum and minimum heights reached by the Ferris wheel during one revolution are 50 meters and 10 meters, respectively.
